annotation.TEXT: Interestingly enough, you still get to fight the Mega Man holograms at the end of this stage (instead of copies of your own Robot Masters). The holograms themselves have 4 phases and come in sets of 2. Rather than using their busters, they'll actually use set weapons from the eight opposing RM's of this game.

Normally I would keep Heat Man out for the next section, though given how time consuming it can be (and a bit convoluted in some regards), I decided to skip it using the Wily Saucer. Normally I wouldn't do this, considering the Saucer would actually make the game go by too quickly, but I can't help but make an exception for this one section (not only does it involve moving platforms and spikes, but also requires Heat Man's dash and the ability to climb ladders - which Heat Man himself is incapable of doing for some reason).

The Yellow Devil functions almost exactly like he does in the original...at least, for his first few cycles. He has quite a few new tricks and movements he can pull off (most of which involve moving sections of his body in larger groups). Much like with the Kamegoro Maker, he also has multiple phases as well.

Now in a phase with even more differences from the original, the Kamegoro Maker itself tries to murder you (by dragging you into the now-broken pipes, which actually causes instant-death should you not struggle to get free in time).

As another note on the music: The current song is actually from RushJet1's remake album of Mega Man 1, and was specifically made for the Yellow Devil fight. Given that it remixes portions of MM3's Wily castle boss theme anyways, I thought it would be fitting enough to use it for this battle.

So then, it's time for the Wily stages. The original MM3's castle is said to be one of the shortest end-game fortresses in the whole series. In this game however, the castle stages are roughly the same length as most of the normal levels (Doc-Robot stages obviously not-withstanding).

Almost all of the castle bosses have been highly modified. The Kamegoro Maker in particular now has 3 new variants of enemies it can produce, each with its own pattern and mechanics (each of the Kamegoro's shells also act differently when the machine picks them up).
Trust me, you want to get rid of these things before exiting the water. They end up being way more annoying than they should be.

For reference, the current song is actually from Mega Man 3 for the Game Boy. This remix is a part of RushJet1's remake album, and was actually used in-place of Wily 2's theme (I think RushJet1 himself said that he didn't like Wily 1's theme that much, and he probably didn't want to do any more renditions on it).
